channel.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
channel.description:
So what I'm wanting to do with said computer is high-end video editing. It needs to be able to handle rendering, editing, intense 3D work and of course play games with ease. Over the months I've put together around $1100NZD. Does anyone think I should keep saving in order to get the PC of my dreams? What parts and brands should I be looking to buy?
I really have no experience with choosing the best parts, because if it were up to me I would just buy what ever has the best price and reviews. But as I understand that some of you tech savy people like to have say in that.
Any help is greatly appreciated.

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

So I decided to buy my parts from New Zealand with the budget of one and half grand. Contacted someone at a webstore and he gave me these components. What do you guys think of them? Don’t have any links sorry.

Read full topic

item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:16, topic:544811”]I’m going to get a nice cheap cooler just to be safe. I also added the wrong storage, thanks for spotting that.
Power Supply: http://pcpartpicker.com/part/corsair-power-supply-rm750
Storage: http://pcpartpicker.com/part/seagate-internal-hard-drive-st2000dm001
And ofc just for you - Case: http://pcpartpicker.com/part/fractal-design-case-fdcadefr4tiw

What do you think of those bad boys?[/quote]Yeah that’s fine!

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:14, topic:544811”]What do you think about this? http://pcpartpicker.com/p/CcXyt6 Spent most of the money on the vitals. The cooler was surprisingly cheap and is rated highly, but I’m probably missing something about it.[/quote]> Don’t need a 1000W power supply, get an ~800W modular.

Don’t need 4TB… Get a 2TB + ~60gb SSD to boot from (stop dling porn).
Don’t need that CPU cooler unless if you’re going to overclock.
Your case looks like my penis, white and clunky. Go get a fractal design case and never look back.
Get a single 8GB module, so you can add more later without using up all of your slots.
Even the MoBo looks excessive but w/e.

Ask us on IRC if you need any more help building this.

Read full topic

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

So it sounds like I’m going to need more dough than I thought. Thanks for the help the 4 of you. Just a couple more questions, how would I know if everything is compatible? And how would I go about choosing a case that’ll fit all the components right?

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

If you get a good GPU and CPU, things like ram can be upgrades slowly. You can always add more ram another time. Motherboards can be fairly expensive too.

Power supply is just as important so don’t think a cheap one is beneficial.

Things like DVD drives and whatnot just get it whenever. Bluray players shouldn’t kill too much of your budget if you want it.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:9, topic:544811”]Well I’m going for intel anyway because after a little bit of research I’ve found that most video editors builds contain i7 for something called hyper threading. From the looks of it I will have to probably save up for another month or so and put together another grand or so. Unless anyone has a recommended build within the budget I have right now?

I also think I’m on my own building this computer, as far as I know there isn’t any stores or anything that can build the comp for me.[/quote]
Your budget is 970 USD, an i7 4770k is going to take up not much less than half of that at $392. The 4770k supports up to 32GB of RAM, you’ll be wanting to use most of that since you’re into hardcore video editing. 4x8GB DDR3 Corsair Vengeance RAM sticks will set you back 275$ at the cheapest I could find. This takes you up to $667 total so far, leaving you with $303 for everything else.

It’s a pretty tight budget if you want a good video editing PC.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

Well I’m going for intel anyway because after a little bit of research I’ve found that most video editors builds contain i7 for something called hyper threading. From the looks of it I will have to probably save up for another month or so and put together another grand or so. Unless anyone has a recommended build within the budget I have right now?

I also think I’m on my own building this computer, as far as I know there isn’t any stores or anything that can build the comp for me.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Don’t listen to Pwnd, the only games he plays on max settings is probably runescape.

Seriously you’re going to want to go for intel. I would personally use AMD if I had half your budget.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

You should absolutely go AMD for a budget PC. I game pretty alright for the GFX card I have. I don’t really have any problems playing games on max settings. I currently have an AMD 6-core, was below $150, I can remember.

Putting together a PC is pretty flippin’ easy once you understand the concept of processor sockets, compatible ram sizes/speeds, motherboard capabilities, etc. Make sure you have enough PCI-E and SATA ports. It’s all really easy.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @FrozenAge FrozenAge
item.description:
@FrozenAge wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:544811”][quote author=FrozenAge link=topic=663689.msg4435559#msg4435559 date=1404983709]
Try iBUYPOWER pre-builds. Avoid AMD processors, use Intel, specifically i7 for those needs, ATI graphics card (otherwise nvidia), of course, it’s going to be a challenge, like Ashi said, really a small budget.
[/quote]

Why avoid AMD cpus? For budget builds they are superior to Intel CPUs.[/quote]

Intel is just a more advanced processor for gaming. I do agree though, for a budget pc, going with Intel, especially seeing as you’re most likely going to go with an ivy bridge, you’re going to need a good cooling system due to the temperatures, so more money needs to be dropped.

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:5, topic:544811”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=663689.msg4435557#msg4435557 date=1404983085]
What I call high end isn’t in your budget.

Just use that pc part picker website, it’s really not that difficult.
[/quote]
This is going to be my very first build and with the limited or next to no knowledge I have of hardware, I would like a little more assistance rather than just a finger towards another website, if possible please.

Try iBUYPOWER pre-builds. Avoid AMD processors, use Intel, specifically i7 for those needs, ATI graphics card (otherwise nvidia), of course, it’s going to be a challenge, like Ashi said, really a small budget.

I’ve had a really bad experience with pre-built computers, they are either really bad and overpriced or they have a ton of software installed that is a pain and a half to remove without problems. My current computer is an in-all-one pre-built and its fine to a certain extent, but when it comes to editing or gaming it gets a bit frustrating. I’ve been looking around the web and I’ve come across this build. Do you think it’ll do the job? I do realize that if I were to get an Intel Core that it should be an i7 because of something like multi threading according to some people. If you haven’t already noticed, I don’t really know what I’m talking about.[/quote]

You could run into many more horrible experiences building the computer yourself, however, whatever you decide on parts (of course after checking into them, making sure they’re all compatible, etc), you could always print the list, and take it to a local PC shop, order the parts, then have them build it for you. Always make sure to get a warranty.

Read full topic
item.source: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC

item.title: Just another nerd needing some help with building a PC
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:2, topic:544811”]What I call high end isn’t in your budget.

Just use that pc part picker website, it’s really not that difficult.[/quote]
This is going to be my very first build and with the limited or next to no knowledge I have of hardware, I would like a little more assistance rather than just a finger towards another website, if possible please.

FrozenAge:

Try iBUYPOWER pre-builds. Avoid AMD processors, use Intel, specifically i7 for those needs, ATI graphics card (otherwise nvidia), of course, it’s going to be a challenge, like Ashi said, really a small budget.

I’ve had a really bad experience with pre-built computers, they are either really bad and overpriced or they have a ton of software installed that is a pain and a half to remove without problems. My current computer is an in-all-one pre-built and its fine to a certain extent, but when it comes to editing or gaming it gets a bit frustrating. I’ve been looking around the web and I’ve come across this build. Do you think it’ll do the job? I do realize that if I were to get an Intel Core that it should be an i7 because of something like multi threading according to some people. If you haven’t already noticed, I don’t really know what I’m talking about.

Read full topic
